articles.headline: Trump Administration Considers a Drastic Cut in Refugees Allowed to Enter U.S.
articles.snippet: Two options administration officials will consider next week would all but end the United States’ status as one of the leading places accepting refugees from around the world.
articles.abstract: Two options administration officials will consider next week would all but end the United States’ status as one of the leading places accepting refugees from around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is considering a plan that would keep most refugees who are fleeing war, persecution and famine out of the United States, significantly cutting back a decades-old program, according to current and former administration officials.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Victoria’s Secret Had Troubles, Even Before Jeffrey Epstein
articles.snippet: L Brands, the brand’s parent company, plans to detail an overhaul next week as it struggles with changing tastes and an embarrassing connection to the Epstein scandal.
articles.abstract: L Brands, the brand’s parent company, plans to detail an overhaul next week as it struggles with changing tastes and an embarrassing connection to the Epstein scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new catalog from Victoria’s Secret landed in mailboxes last month, igniting a flurry of texts and emails among former executives.

articles.headline: On Dorian-Battered Island, What’s Left? Virtually Nothing
articles.snippet: “This ain’t no place for anyone at the moment,” said one resident of devastated Abaco Island in the Bahamas.
articles.abstract: “This ain’t no place for anyone at the moment,” said one resident of devastated Abaco Island in the Bahamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSH HARBOUR, Bahamas — No schools. No banks. No gas stations. No supermarkets. No restaurants. No churches. No pharmacies. No hardware stores. No water, no electricity and no phone lines.

articles.headline: A Presidential Storm Leaves Forecasters Rebuked
articles.snippet: The parent agency of the National Weather Service’s Birmingham, Ala., office issued a statement admonishing it for challenging President Trump’s claim about a hurricane threat to Alabama.
articles.abstract: The parent agency of the National Weather Service’s Birmingham, Ala., office issued a statement admonishing it for challenging President Trump’s claim about a hurricane threat to Alabama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The hurricane was accelerating away from the Mid-Atlantic coast. In the Bahamas, victims were picking through the devastation. In the Southeast, they were cleaning up debris. And in Washington, President Trump waged war over his forecasting skills.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Is Xi Mishandling Hong Kong Crisis? Hints of Unease in China’s Leadership
articles.snippet: Beijing’s halting response to the protests in Hong Kong has raised questions about President Xi Jinping’s imperious style and authoritarian policies.
articles.abstract: Beijing’s halting response to the protests in Hong Kong has raised questions about President Xi Jinping’s imperious style and authoritarian policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, warned a gathering of senior Communist Party officials in January that the country faced a raft of urgent economic and political risks, and told them to be on guard especially for “indolence, incompetence and becoming divorced from the public.”
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Cheating, Inc.: How Writing Papers for American College Students Has Become a Lucrative Profession Overseas
articles.snippet: Amid the college admissions scandal, another type of cheating was overlooked: Students already in college who pay others to write their papers.
articles.abstract: Amid the college admissions scandal, another type of cheating was overlooked: Students already in college who pay others to write their papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tuition was due. The rent was, too. So Mary Mbugua, a university student in Nyeri, Kenya, went out in search of a job. At first, she tried selling insurance policies, but that only paid on commission and she never sold one. Then she sat behind the reception desk at a hotel, but it ran into financial trouble.

articles.headline: Biden Wants to Work With ‘the Other Side.’ This Supreme Court Battle Explains Why.
articles.snippet: In the clash over Robert H. Bork’s nomination, Joe Biden’s moderate instincts defined a winning strategy.
articles.abstract: In the clash over Robert H. Bork’s nomination, Joe Biden’s moderate instincts defined a winning strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was on the brink of victory, but he was unsatisfied.

articles.headline: Checking In at Trump Hotels, for Kinship (and Maybe Some Sway)
articles.snippet: To ethics lawyers, the most extraordinary aspect of the daily merging of President Trump’s official duties and his commercial interests is that it has now become almost routine.
articles.abstract: To ethics lawyers, the most extraordinary aspect of the daily merging of President Trump’s official duties and his commercial interests is that it has now become almost routine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a table in the lobby bar of the Trump International Hotel this week, the final details of a black-tie, 40th anniversary gala for the Concerned Women for America were being worked out by the conservative group’s staff.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Director of M.I.T.’s Media Lab Resigns After Taking Money From Jeffrey Epstein
articles.snippet: Joichi Ito had acknowledged taking $525,000 for the lab from Mr. Epstein, as well as more than $1 million for his own investment funds.
articles.abstract: Joichi Ito had acknowledged taking $525,000 for the lab from Mr. Epstein, as well as more than $1 million for his own investment funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after his death, Jeffrey Epstein continues to haunt some of America’s most prestigious institutions.
articles.byline: By Marc Tracy and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Trump Says He’s Called Off Negotiations With Taliban After Afghanistan Bombing
articles.snippet: The president said he had canceled a secret meeting at Camp David with Taliban leaders and the president of Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The president said he had canceled a secret meeting at Camp David with Taliban leaders and the president of Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he had canceled a secret meeting at Camp David with Taliban leaders and the president of Afghanistan and was calling off monthslong negotiations that had appeared to be nearing a peace agreement.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley, Lara Jakes and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: How Top-Valued Microsoft Has Avoided the Big Tech Backlash
articles.snippet: Its “Evil Empire” moniker, once a label favored by the company’s critics, has fallen by the wayside.
articles.abstract: Its “Evil Empire” moniker, once a label favored by the company’s critics, has fallen by the wayside.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple are targets of government investigations and public outrage, facing accusations that they abuse their power in various ways, from exploiting personal information to stifling rivals.

articles.headline: After Trump Calls Off Talks, Afghanistan Braces for Violence
articles.snippet: There were many questions about why Mr. Trump suddenly scuttled talks with the Taliban just as they were nearing a conclusion.
articles.abstract: There were many questions about why Mr. Trump suddenly scuttled talks with the Taliban just as they were nearing a conclusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to break off peace talks with the Taliban, at least for now, left Afghanistan bracing for a bloody prelude to national elections this month, while the administration declined on Sunday to rule out a withdrawal of American troops without a peace accord.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: Democrats to Broaden Impeachment Inquiry Into Trump to Corruption Accusations
articles.snippet: Lawmakers plan to examine claims that the president dangled pardons to aides and that his resorts illegally profited from government business.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers plan to examine claims that the president dangled pardons to aides and that his resorts illegally profited from government business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats return to Washington this week poised to significantly broaden their nascent impeachment inquiry into President Trump beyond the findings of the Russia investigation, but they will confront a fast-dwindling political clock.

articles.headline: How Each Big Tech Company May Be Targeted by Regulators
articles.snippet: While Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have all drawn attention to how they dominate markets, the reasons are as different as the companies.
articles.abstract: While Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have all drawn attention to how they dominate markets, the reasons are as different as the companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have been the envy of corporate America, admired for their size, influence and remarkable growth.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Karen Weise and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Nissan Board Set to Meet as It Faces a Leadership Crisis
articles.snippet: Nissan’s board of directors will meet on Monday as the company confronts increasing doubts about the future of its chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa.
articles.abstract: Nissan’s board of directors will meet on Monday as the company confronts increasing doubts about the future of its chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nissan’s board of directors is set to meet on Monday as the company’s top executive, Hiroto Saikawa, faces a widening crisis of confidence in his leadership.

articles.headline: The World Wastes Tons of Food. A Grocery ‘Happy Hour’ Is One Answer.
articles.snippet: Groceries and companies in Europe are cooperating with consumers to reduce $680 billion in food waste each year. Food near expiration turns into bargains.
articles.abstract: Groceries and companies in Europe are cooperating with consumers to reduce $680 billion in food waste each year. Food near expiration turns into bargains.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — “Happy hour” at the S-market store in the working-class neighborhood of Vallila happens far from the liquor aisles and isn’t exactly convivial. Nobody is here for drinks or a good time. They’re looking for a steep discount on a slab of pork.

articles.headline: How Trump’s Plan to Secretly Meet With the Taliban Came Together, and Fell Apart
articles.snippet: What would have been one of the biggest headline-grabbing moments of President Trump’s tenure was put together on the spur of the moment and then canceled on the spur of the moment.
articles.abstract: What would have been one of the biggest headline-grabbing moments of President Trump’s tenure was put together on the spur of the moment and then canceled on the spur of the moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the Friday before Labor Day, President Trump gathered top advisers in the Situation Room to consider what could be among the profound decisions of his presidency — a peace plan with the Taliban after 18 years of grinding, bloody war in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Mujib Mashal and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: How Elizabeth Warren Raised Big Money Before She Denounced Big Money
articles.snippet: Ms. Warren wooed wealthy donors for years, stockpiling money from fund-raisers, and has used $10.4 million from her 2018 Senate race to underwrite her 2020 bid.
articles.abstract: Ms. Warren wooed wealthy donors for years, stockpiling money from fund-raisers, and has used $10.4 million from her 2018 Senate race to underwrite her 2020 bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the highest floor of the tallest building in Boston, Senator Elizabeth Warren was busy collecting big checks from some of the city’s politically connected insiders. It was April 2018 and Ms. Warren, up for re-election, was at a breakfast fund-raiser hosted for her by John M. Connors Jr., one of the old-guard power brokers of Massachusetts.

articles.headline: Nissan Takes Another Hit as C.E.O. Hiroto Saikawa Leaves
articles.snippet: Mr. Saikawa’s departure follows months of speculation about his ability to manage the Japanese carmaker since the ouster of its former chairman, Carlos Ghosn.
articles.abstract: Mr. Saikawa’s departure follows months of speculation about his ability to manage the Japanese carmaker since the ouster of its former chairman, Carlos Ghosn.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — In less than a year Nissan has lost its chairman to a financial misconduct scandal; its profits have plummeted; and its ties to Renault, often seen as crucial for its future, have fallen apart. And now, its embattled chief executive is leaving in the shadow of a pay scandal.

articles.headline: A Hedge Fund Becomes a Very Noisy Stakeholder in AT&T
articles.snippet: Run by a donor to President Trump, Paul Singer, Elliott Management issues a letter sharply critical of the company’s move into Hollywood.
articles.abstract: Run by a donor to President Trump, Paul Singer, Elliott Management issues a letter sharply critical of the company’s move into Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its $85.4 billion purchase of Time Warner last year, AT&T announced to the world that it was becoming a new kind of corporate behemoth, one that would be a force in media and entertainment while also maintaining its dominant position in the telecommunications industry.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Edmund Lee
